skill.name: web-browser
skill.description: Allows to interact with web pages by performing actions such as clicking buttons, filling out forms, and navigating links. It works by remote controlling Google Chrome or Chromium browsers using the Chrome DevTools Protocol (CDP). When Claude needs to browse the web, it can use this skill to do so.
skill.summary: Allows to interact with web pages by performing actions such as clicking buttons, filling out forms,...
skill.author: Dwsy

security_audit.summary: Legitimate browser automation skill using Chrome DevTools Protocol. Accesses filesystem for profile management and temp files, executes shell commands to manage Chrome processes, and connects to localhost CDP port. All behaviors align with stated purpose.

medium_findings.title: Chrome process management via shell commands
medium_findings.description: The start.js script executes shell commands to kill existing Chrome processes and start new Chrome instances. Code: `execSync("killall 'Google Chrome'")` at line 22 and `spawn(...)` at line 40. While this is standard for browser automation, shell process manipulation requires user trust.

medium_findings.title: Chrome profile directory access and rsync operation
medium_findings.description: When --profile flag is used, the skill copies the entire Chrome profile directory using rsync. Code accesses `~/Library/Application Support/Google/Chrome/` and syncs to `~/.cache/scraping`. This includes cookies, login credentials, and browsing history. Users should understand this copies sensitive authentication data.

low_findings.title: Temporary file writes for screenshots
low_findings.description: Screenshot capability writes PNG files to OS temp directory. Code: `join(tmpdir(), filename)` at line 21 in screenshot.js. Standard practice but temp files may persist temporarily.

low_findings.title: Environment variable access for home directory
low_findings.description: Accesses process.env["HOME"] to locate Chrome profile and user data directories. Standard pattern but reveals filesystem paths to skill.

content.user_title: Control Chrome Browser for Web Automation
content.value_statement: AI assistants cannot browse the web natively. This skill adds browser control capabilities including navigation, element interaction, JavaScript execution, and screenshots using Chrome DevTools Protocol.
actual_capabilities: Start Chrome with remote debugging on port 9222
Navigate to URLs and open new browser tabs
Execute JavaScript in active browser context
Select and identify page elements visually
Copy existing Chrome profile with cookies and logins
limitations: Requires Google Chrome or Chromium installed on the system
Chrome must be manually started before use
Does not handle complex authentication flows automatically
JavaScript execution runs in async context only

use_cases.title: Extract Data from Web Pages
use_cases.description: Navigate research sites, extract links, and capture page content programmatically.

use_cases.title: Test Web Applications
use_cases.description: Automate form submissions, click buttons, and verify page elements during development.

use_cases.title: Capture Web Page Screenshots
use_cases.description: Take screenshots of web pages and identify specific elements visually.

prompt_templates.title: Navigate to Website
prompt_templates.prompt: Go to https://example.com and tell me the page title.

prompt_templates.title: Extract Links
prompt_templates.prompt: Find all external links on this page and list their URLs.

prompt_templates.title: Interactive Element Selection
prompt_templates.prompt: Pick the submit button on this page so I can click it later.

prompt_templates.title: Capture Visual State
prompt_templates.prompt: Take a screenshot of the current page view.

output_examples.input: Go to https://example.com and find all links

best_practices: Start Chrome fresh or with a dedicated profile to avoid mixing personal data
Use element picker for complex pages to get accurate selectors
Close browser when done to free system resources
anti_patterns: Running with your primary Chrome profile exposes cookies and credentials
Leaving Chrome running indefinitely consumes memory and CPU
Assuming all JavaScript will execute correctly in the async context

faq.question: Which browsers are supported?
faq.answer: Google Chrome and Chromium-based browsers are fully supported. Other browsers require manual configuration.

faq.question: What are the performance limits?
faq.answer: Screenshots are limited by viewport size. JavaScript execution timeout is 30 seconds per command.

faq.question: How does it integrate with Claude?
faq.answer: The skill provides MCP-compatible tools that Claude can invoke for navigation, evaluation, and interaction.

faq.question: Is my browsing data safe?
faq.answer: Data stays on your machine. Profile copying is optional. No data is sent to external servers.

faq.question: Why is Chrome not connecting?
faq.answer: Ensure Chrome is running with --remote-debugging-port=9222. Check no other process is using that port.

faq.question: How is this different from puppeteer?
faq.answer: This uses an existing Chrome installation rather than launching a headless browser, preserving your session state.
